notes.title: Ulothrix — Complete Life Cycle (with diagrams)
notes.content: Filamentous green alga (Chlorophyta) with haplontic cycle: asexual zoospores; isogamous gametes → zygote (2n) → zygotic meiosis → haploid filaments.
keyTakeaways: Zygotic meiosis restores haploidy; classic haplontic pattern.
Compare with Spirogyra and Oedogonium for exam contrasts.

resources.title: Seedless plants & alternation of generations (life cycle context)

notes.title: Marchantia — Habitat, Structure & Reproduction
notes.content: Thalloid liverwort; dorsiventral thallus with air chambers; gemma cups (asexual); antheridiophores & archegoniophores (sexual); sporophyte dependent on gametophyte.
keyTakeaways: Draw gemma cups and male/female receptacles clearly.
Lifecycle shows embryo retention on gametophyte.

notes.title: Evolution of the Seed & Its Importance
notes.content: Transition from homospory → heterospory → seed habit; seeds confer protection, dormancy, dispersal, and embryo nourishment — key to terrestrial success of spermatophytes.
keyTakeaways: Seeds reduce water dependence; enable dormancy & wider dispersal.

notes.title: Angiosperm Fertilization & Double Fertilization
notes.content: Pollen tube delivers two sperm cells: one fuses with egg (zygote), the other with central cell (polar nuclei) to form endosperm — hallmark of angiosperms.
keyTakeaways: Sequence: pollination → germination → tube growth → syngamy + triple fusion.

notes.title: Algae — Classification, Pigments & Economic Importance
notes.content: Major groups by pigments, storage products, and cell structure (Chlorophyta, Rhodophyta, Phaeophyceae, Cyanobacteria); roles in food, biofertilizers, and industry.
keyTakeaways: Match pigment sets (chlorophylls, carotenoids, phycobilins) to groups.

resources.title: Seedless plants (algal context in plant evolution)

notes.title: Rhizopus — Structure, Nutrition & Reproduction
notes.content: Zygomycete fungus with coenocytic hyphae; saprophytic nutrition; asexual sporangiospores; sexual zygospores via gametangial copulation.
keyTakeaways: Roles in spoilage, fermentation, and research.

notes.title: Lichens — Symbiosis, Reproduction & Importance
notes.content: Stable association of mycobiont (fungus) and phycobiont (alga/cyanobacterium); sexual reproduction by fungal partner; asexual via soredia/isidia; bioindicators & soil formation.
keyTakeaways: Understand dual nature and ecological resilience.
Use in biomonitoring air quality; pioneer species on rocks.

resources.title: Pollen & palynology (context for lichen spores not primary, but ecosystem indicators)

notes.title: Bryophytes — Characteristics, Evolution & Reproduction
notes.content: Non-vascular land plants with dominant gametophyte; need free water for fertilization; sporophyte remains attached; vegetative reproduction via gemmae (e.g., Marchantia).
keyTakeaways: Dominant gametophyte is a core hallmark.
Life cycle alternates n ↔ 2n with zygote retained.

notes.title: Evolution of Gametophyte & Sporophyte in Bryophytes
notes.content: Trends in dependency and complexity; sporophyte evolution from simple seta+capsule to more elaborate forms; implications for land adaptation.
keyTakeaways: Sporophyte is nutritionally dependent in bryophytes.
Evolution increases sporophyte specialization while retaining dependence.
Contrast with vascular plants where sporophyte dominates.

notes.title: Pteridophytes — Equisetum (Strobilus & Sporangia)
notes.content: Horsetails with jointed stems and silica; strobili bear sporangiophores with sporangia; homosporous; elaters aid spore dispersal.
keyTakeaways: Know strobilus organization and sporangiophore structure.

notes.title: Gymnosperms vs Pteridophytes (and vs Angiosperms) — Core Contrasts
notes.content: Gymnosperms: seeds naked on cones, no flowers/fruits; Pteridophytes: seedless vascular, spore-based; Angiosperms: flowers, fruits, double fertilization.
keyTakeaways: Seed presence/absence is the key divide.
Cone-based reproduction central to many gymnosperms.

notes.title: Classification Systems — Artificial, Natural & Phylogenetic
notes.content: Artificial systems use few superficial characters (e.g., Linnaeus). Natural systems consider many characters (Bentham & Hooker). Phylogenetic systems (APG) use evolutionary/molecular data.
keyTakeaways: Natural: reflects more relationships but still morphology-based.

notes.title: Binomial Nomenclature & ICN Rules
notes.content: Binomial system (Linnaeus, 1753); governed by ICN (International Code of Nomenclature); principles include priority, typification, Latinization.
keyTakeaways: Every plant has one correct scientific name.
ICN applies to algae, fungi, and plants.

notes.title: Palynology & Taxonomic Significance
notes.content: Palynology studies pollen/spore morphology. Used in taxonomy, palaeoecology, climate reconstructions, and forensics.
keyTakeaways: Exine sculpturing and apertures help ID taxa.

notes.title: Modern Biosystematics — Morphological, Molecular, Numerical
notes.content: Biosystematics integrates classical taxonomy with cytology, molecular phylogenetics, chemotaxonomy, palynology, and numerical methods.
keyTakeaways: Numerical taxonomy uses algorithms and clustering.
Chemo-taxonomy uses secondary metabolites as characters.

notes.title: Cambium & Secondary Growth
notes.content: Vascular cambium (fusiform & ray initials) produces secondary xylem & phloem. Cork cambium forms periderm. Secondary growth thickens stems & roots in dicots/gymnosperms.
keyTakeaways: Vascular cambium = wood and secondary phloem.
Not present in monocots (with few exceptions).

notes.title: Meristematic Tissues
notes.content: Apical, intercalary, and lateral meristems. Primary growth via apical; secondary growth via lateral (cambium).
keyTakeaways: Meristems are undifferentiated, capable of division.
Intercalary meristems in grasses allow regrowth.

notes.title: Poaceae Family — Diagnostic Characters & Economic Importance
notes.content: Grass family with hollow stems, nodes, sheathing leaves, spikelets. Economically most important family (cereals, sugarcane, bamboo).
keyTakeaways: Major crops: wheat, rice, maize, sugarcane.

notes.title: Stomata, Cell Walls & Tissue Ultrastructure
notes.content: Guard cells control gas exchange; cell wall layers (primary, secondary, middle lamella); specialized tissues (xylem, phloem, collenchyma, sclerenchyma).
keyTakeaways: Stomata distribution adapts to habitat (xerophytes vs hydrophytes).
Cell wall = cellulose microfibrils + lignin in secondary.
Parenchyma vs collenchyma vs sclerenchyma differences.

notes.title: Photosynthesis — Light Reactions & Z-Scheme
notes.content: Light energy drives electron flow through PSII → plastoquinone → cytochrome b6f → plastocyanin → PSI → ferredoxin → NADP+. Proton gradient powers ATP synthesis.
keyTakeaways: Z-scheme shows PSII and PSI operating sequentially.
Produces ATP and NADPH for Calvin cycle.

notes.title: C3, C4 & CAM Photosynthesis
notes.content: C3: Calvin cycle directly fixes CO2. C4: spatial separation of initial fixation (PEP carboxylase in mesophyll) and Calvin cycle in bundle sheath. CAM: temporal separation (night fixation, day Calvin cycle).
keyTakeaways: C4 plants (e.g., maize) reduce photorespiration in hot climates.
CAM plants (e.g., cacti) adapt to arid environments.
Know enzyme differences: RuBisCO vs PEP carboxylase.

notes.title: Respiration — Glycolysis, TCA Cycle, Oxidative Phosphorylation
notes.content: Glycolysis in cytoplasm → pyruvate oxidation → TCA in mitochondria → NADH/FADH2 donate e- to ETC → ATP by chemiosmosis.
keyTakeaways: TCA produces 3 NADH + 1 FADH2 + 1 GTP per acetyl-CoA.
ETC in inner mitochondrial membrane drives proton gradient.

notes.title: Plant Hormones & Growth Regulators
notes.content: Auxins: apical dominance, cell elongation; Gibberellins: stem elongation, seed germination; Cytokinins: cell division, delay senescence; ABA: stress hormone, dormancy; Ethylene: fruit ripening.
keyTakeaways: Know sites of biosynthesis (e.g., auxin in shoot tips, gibberellins in seeds).
ABA crucial in stomatal closure during drought.

notes.title: RuBisCO & Enzyme Specificity
notes.content: Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase catalyzes CO2 fixation in Calvin cycle but also O2 fixation (photorespiration).
keyTakeaways: Enzyme active site allows both CO2 and O2 binding.
Carboxylase activity drives Calvin cycle; oxygenase → photorespiration.

notes.title: Nitrogen Cycle & Human Impacts
notes.content: Steps: fixation (biological/industrial), nitrification, assimilation, ammonification, denitrification. Human inputs (fertilizers, industry) disrupt balance.
keyTakeaways: N2O emissions contribute to climate change.

notes.title: Ecosystem Concept & Components
notes.content: Ecosystem = community of organisms + abiotic environment. Structure: producers, consumers, decomposers; functions: energy flow, nutrient cycling.

notes.title: Plant Succession
notes.content: Gradual, directional change in community composition. Primary succession (bare substrate), secondary succession (disturbed habitat). Hydrosere = succession in aquatic habitats.
keyTakeaways: Hydrosere: phytoplankton → submerged → reed swamp → forest.

notes.title: Soil Formation & Abiotic Factors
notes.content: Soil forms via weathering of parent rock, influenced by climate, organisms, relief, and time. Abiotic factors like water, temperature, and wind shape soil properties.
keyTakeaways: Abiotic factors influence soil texture and fertility.
Waterlogging and salinity are major issues in Pakistan.

notes.title: Xerophytes — Structural Adaptations
notes.content: Plants in arid environments show thick cuticle, sunken stomata, CAM photosynthesis, water-storing tissues, spines for leaves.
keyTakeaways: Reduced surface area minimizes water loss.

notes.title: Pollution — Aquatic & Terrestrial
notes.content: Aquatic pollution from eutrophication, industrial effluents; terrestrial from soil contamination, pesticides, heavy metals. Affects biodiversity and human health.

notes.title: Late Blight of Potato (Phytophthora infestans)
notes.content: Pathogen causes devastating potato disease. Lifecycle involves sporangia, zoospores, infection cycles. Controlled by resistant cultivars, fungicides, cultural practices.
keyTakeaways: Spread enhanced by cool, moist weather.

notes.title: Soil Salinity & Waterlogging in Pakistan
notes.content: Indus Basin irrigation caused secondary salinity and waterlogging. Control: drainage, leaching, salt-tolerant crops, improved irrigation management.
keyTakeaways: Reclamation: tube wells, gypsum application, salt-tolerant varieties.

notes.title: Biodiversity & Conservation
notes.content: Biodiversity = variety of species, ecosystems, genes. Conservation ensures ecosystem services, stability, and resilience.
keyTakeaways: In-situ: protected areas; ex-situ: seed banks, botanical gardens.
Essential to counter biodiversity loss from pollution & deforestation.

notes.title: Phytoremediation — Plants as Pollution Mitigators
notes.content: Plants used to remove, degrade, or stabilize pollutants from soil/water. Strategies: phytoextraction, phytodegradation, rhizofiltration, phytostabilization.
keyTakeaways: Poplar/willow used in phytodegradation of organics.

notes.title: Mendelian Genetics — Laws of Segregation & Independent Assortment
notes.content: Mendel's pea experiments → law of segregation (alleles separate) and independent assortment (alleles assort independently in gametes).

notes.title: DNA Structure & Double Helix
notes.content: Watson and Crick (1953) proposed DNA double helix; uniform 2 nm diameter; base-pairing (A=T, G≡C); antiparallel strands.

notes.title: Linkage & Morgan's Drosophila Experiments
notes.content: Morgan showed genes are linked on chromosomes (fruit fly eye color & wing shape). Linkage modifies Mendelian ratios.
keyTakeaways: Crossing over during meiosis breaks linkage.
Foundation of chromosomal theory of inheritance.

notes.title: Mutations & Mutagens
notes.content: Mutation = heritable change in DNA. Types: point mutations, insertions/deletions, chromosomal aberrations. Mutagens: radiation, chemicals, viruses.
keyTakeaways: Silent, missense, nonsense mutations differ by protein effect.

notes.title: Genetic Engineering Tools — Plasmids & λ Phage Vectors
notes.content: Plasmids are circular DNA molecules used as cloning vectors. λ phage vector allows larger DNA inserts and high efficiency.
keyTakeaways: Plasmids carry selectable markers & origin of replication.
λ vectors useful in genomic libraries.
Vectors are essential for recombinant DNA technology.

notes.title: Nucleus — Ultrastructure
notes.content: Nucleus has double membrane with pores; nucleoplasm, nucleolus, chromatin. Pore complexes regulate transport.

notes.title: Photosystems in Thylakoid Membranes
notes.content: PSII in grana thylakoids; PSI in stroma lamellae; cyclic vs non-cyclic electron flow. Light harvesting complexes funnel energy to reaction centers.
keyTakeaways: PSII produces O2 by splitting water.
Spatial separation visible in EM studies.

notes.title: Krebs Cycle — Diagram & Significance
notes.content: Acetyl-CoA enters cycle; produces NADH, FADH2, GTP; CO2 released; intermediates link to amino acid and lipid metabolism.
keyTakeaways: Diagram with intermediates is exam standard.

notes.title: Short Notes — Quick Revision Topics
notes.content: Exam papers often ask short notes on topics like: photoperiodism, vernalization, food webs, Hardy-Weinberg, enzyme specificity, numerical taxonomy.
